data.title: Farmers and consumers market bulletin, vol. 82 [i.e. 78], no. 20 (1995 May 17)
data.text:
GEORGIA DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE TOMMY IRVIN,COMMISSIONER

Vol. 78, No. 20____________________

Pecan Referendum Set

The Commodity Commission for Pecans will hold a 30-day referendum period from May 8 through June 6, 1995 to vote on the Proposed Marketing Order for Pecans.

Ballots have been mailed to producers with 30 acres or more.

The affected producers will have 30 days in which to vote on the one-half cent (1/20) per pound assessment. Monies col lected from the assessment will be used to fund programs of research, education and promotion on behalf of Georgia pecans.

At least 25 percent of the affected pro ducers must vote in the referendum and a 66 2/3 percent favorable vote must be received for the Marketing Order to become effective.

Recipe Contest Showcases Georgia's Great Tastes

May 31 is the deadline for the "Great Tastes of Georgia Recipe Contest" planned for the Atlanta State Farmers' Market for June 24. Coordinated by the Georgia Department of Agriculture, the contest will give participants the chance to compete for $3,400 in prize money.

Fifteen top finalists will be selected for each category. The finalists will be asked to prepare dishes at home and bring them to the farmers' market in Forest Park for judging and sampling. Each recipe must include a principle ingredient of at least one fresh Georgia-grown prod uct. Recipes which ordinarily contain eggs and milk must also include another Georgia-grown product as the principle ingredient.

Recipes will be judged on taste, origi nality and use of Georgia products. Prizes will be awarded to the first, second and third place winners in each of four cate gories: main dish, side dish (salad, casse role, etc.), dessert and light cuisine (recipes low in fat, sodium, calories, etc.). A total' of $850 will be awarded to win ners in each category - first - $500; second-$250 and third-$100. Winning recipes in contests previously held in Savannah and Macon are ineligible for the Atlanta contest.

The contest is open to Georgia resi dents 16 years of age or older. Food pro fessionals, restaurants and employees and families of the Georgia Department of Agriculture are not eligible to participate. An official entry form must be used to enter the contest.

To receive a detailed copy of the offi cial entry form, which lists specific rules, send a self-addressed stamped envelope to Great Tastes of Georgia Recipe Contest, Room 328, Agriculture Building, Atlanta, GA 30334.

Wednesday, May 17, 1995

ag consumer line...

I would like to know how caffeine is removed from coffee and also the best way to store ground coffee.

The caffeine is removed from the coffee beans before they are roasted by one of two methods. In the first method, the caffeine is chemically extracted by use of a sol vent, which is completely washed away before the beans are dried. Research has shown that, should any residues remain, they disappear entirely when the beans are roasted.

In the second method, called Swiss water process, the beans are steamed, then the caffeine-rich outer layers are scraped away.

To help preserve the flavor, ground coffee should be refrigerated in an airtight container. For best results, use within two weeks. To obtain the most flavorful brew, coffee connoisseurs recommend buying fresh whole beans and grinding them your self. Grind only enough to make a pot because ground beans lose their flavor quick ly. Whole beans also lose flavor quickly, so they should be stored in an airtight con tainer in a cool, dry place for up to two weeks. For longer storage, whole beans may be wrapped in freezer wrap and kept frozen for three months.

If you have problems or questions concerning products or services regulated by the Georgia Department of Agriculture, write: Consumer Services, Room 226, Agriculture Building, 19 ML. King, Jr. Dr., Atlanta, Georgia 30334-4201, or call toll-free, 1 -800-2825852 or in metro Atlanta, 656-3645.

What's in Season

Vidalia Onion Season in Full Swing in Ga.

The season for the world-famous and home-grown Vidalia onions is now in full swing and available at farmers' mar kets and grocery stores around the state.

Vidalias are sweet, yellow onions grown exclusively in a 20-county region in Georgia, but loved by consumers all over North America. Their mild, sweet taste makes Vidalia onions more versa tile than onions with a stronger taste. Vidalia onions are available from late April through mid-July. The crop is planted from September through February each year, with 70,000 plants produced on each acre.

Similar onion hybrids are grown in other parts of the country, but the combi nation of sandy soil and mild climate pro vide the Vidalia onion with its distinct flavor. Vidalia onions are a good source of vitamin C and dietary fiber, while low in calories and fat, and cholesterol free.

Vidalia Onions Are Good For You

Nutrient analysis: Serving size 1 medium onion (150 g) Calories 60 Protein 1 g Carbohydrate 14 g Fat 0 g Cholesterol 0 g Sodium 10 mg Calcium 38 mg Dietary fiber 3 g

A Buyer's Guide to Vidalia Onions Vidalia onions should have a light,

golden-brown bulb and a white interior. They should be rounded on the bottomand slightly flat on the top.

Vidalia-onions bruise fairly easily, so handle them carefully.

To enjoy Vidalia onions longer than the 10-12 weeks they're available each year, buy in large quantities and store them properly.

Keep Vidalia onions cool, dry and separate to ensure they stay fresh.

Or, store them in the legs of old, clean, sheer pantyhose.

Tie a knot between each onion, and cut above the knot when you need an onion. Hang Vidalia onions in a cool, dry, wellventilated area.

Vidalia onions also can be stored on racks or screens as long as they don't touch and are kept in a cool place.

To freeze chopped Vidalia onions, chop the onions and place on a cookie sheet in the freezer. When frozen, remove and place in freezer containers or bags, and seal.

To freeze a whole Vidalia onion, peel, wash, core and place onion in a freezer bag. Frozen onions should be used for baking, because freezing changes their texture.

Fun Facts About Vidalia Onions Vidalia onions are the state vegetable of Georgia. Vidalia onions were first grown more than 60 years ago in Toombs County, Georgia by Mose Coleman. Coleman was surprised to find that the onions he plant ed were sweet, not hot. When Coleman's sweet onions gar nered a high price, other area farmers began planting onions.

Please accept our sincere appreciation for your generosity and continued dedi cation to the Bulletin.

Commissioner Tommy Irvin and the Market Bulletin Staff

Special Handicraft Edition See Ads pages 11-12

Next Handicraft Edition

The next handicraft edition of the Market Bulletin is scheduled for June 21. The deadline for notices is June 7.

All items advertised in the Handicraft category must be handmade by the adver tiser and not purchased for resale.

Handicraft adware limited to 30 words and must be in compliance with all other advertising guidelines (see page 2).

Equestrian Society Offers New Guide to Horses in Ga.

The Atlanta Equestrian Society's new Guide to Horses in Georgia is now avail able. Printed by the Society and the Georgia Department of Agriculture, the directory includes the name and contact numbers for the state's major club and breed organiza tions, equine veterinarians, Cooperative Extension Service agents specializing in equine, show grounds and areas, equine publications, and public horse trails and facilities for riding vacations.

To order a copy of the guide, send $2.50 for mailing and handling to: Guide to Horses in Georgia, P.O. Box 328, Jersey, GA 30235. Make checks payable to Guide to Horses in Georgia.

Farm Front

Bobby J. Neill, a forest landowner and consulting forester from Magnolia. Arkansas, was recently installed as president of the Atlanta-based Forest Farmers Association during its 54th annual meeting held recently in Asheville, North Carolina.

Forest landowner and consulting forester W.H. "Ace" Parker. Jr. of Salisbury, Maryland was named presi dent-elect and will lake office at the end of Neill's one-year term.

The Forest Farmers Association represents limherland owners in 16 southern states.
